title: Emotional Safety
description: Explore what emotional safety means for your intimate connection.

choices: Knowing I won't be judged or criticized
Feeling fully accepted and loved
Being able to be my authentic self
All of these—safety is multifaceted

therapeutic.rationale: Emotional safety definitions shape what you need. Non-judgment seekers fear criticism; acceptance-needers want unconditional love; authenticity-seekers want freedom to be real; multifaceted types need all three. Naming your definition helps your partner provide it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: All these aspects of safety matter—emphasize what your partner most needs while maintaining all three.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared safety definition focuses your effort on the same target.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What does emotional safety during intimacy mean to you? When do you feel safest?

questions.text: What would make me feel less safe emotionally during intimacy is...
choices: Criticism or negative comments about my body
Feeling rushed or pressured
Sensing my partner is distracted or checked out
Lack of emotional connection before physical

therapeutic.rationale: Knowing what threatens safety helps partners avoid it. Criticism-sensitive types need affirmation; pressure-averse types need patience; presence-needers want attention; connection-needers want emotional depth first. These are often unspoken.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Avoid ALL of these threats regardless of your own vulnerability pattern. Your partner's safety triggers matter as much as yours.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared vulnerability pattern means you'll instinctively avoid hurting each other in the same ways.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes you feel emotionally unsafe during intimacy? Has that happened before? What did you need?

questions.text: After an intimate moment, what I most need emotionally is...
choices: Continued closeness and affection
Verbal affirmation and connection
Quiet presence without words
To feel like it meant something to my partner

therapeutic.rationale: Post-intimacy emotional needs vary. Closeness-needers want physical continuation; verbal-needers want words; quiet-presence types want peaceful together-time; meaning-seekers want validation. Aftercare is often overlooked but crucial for safety.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different needs require different giving. The closeness-needer may cling when their partner needs quiet; the quiet-needer may seem distant. Share and honor each other's needs.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched aftercare needs make post-intimacy transitions seamless.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you need emotionally after being intimate? Are you getting that now?

questions.text: When I share something vulnerable about intimacy, I need my partner to...
choices: Listen without trying to fix it
Reassure me that it's okay
Share something vulnerable too
Remember it and honor it going forward

therapeutic.rationale: Vulnerability responses shape whether we share again. Listeners validate; reassurers comfort; mutual-sharers connect; rememberers demonstrate care. The wrong response shuts down future vulnerability.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different needs require different responses. Ask what your partner needs before launching into your default mode.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched vulnerability response needs make processing intimate vulnerability together natural.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When you share something vulnerable, what response helps? What doesn't?

questions.text: I feel emotionally closest to my partner during intimacy when...
choices: There's eye contact and presence
We communicate throughout
I feel completely desired and wanted
We're emotionally connected before we begin

therapeutic.rationale: Closeness triggers vary. Eye-contact types need visual connection; communicators need verbal exchange; desired-feelers need to feel wanted; pre-connectors need emotional warmth first. Knowing your partner's trigger helps you create it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different triggers are fine—you can provide all of these with awareness. Learn what your partner most needs.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared closeness trigger makes deep connection during intimacy easier.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When do you feel most emotionally close during intimacy? What creates that feeling?
